data.title: META’s selloff affects over 600 ETFs, but these 10 funds have the most exposure
data.description:
Shares of Meta Platforms (META) sank sharply on Thursday, dropping more than 12% after the social media giant reported earnings that fell short of expectations.

The steep decline in META weighed heavily not only on its own stock but also on the broader tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) and rattled investor sentiment across multiple exchange-traded funds with significant META exposure. 

The California-based tech giant is currently held in 637 ETFs, collectively owning over 309 million shares. The pullback underscores META’s outsized influence on tech-focused markets, highlighting how disappointing results from a single mega cap can ripple across the broader investment landscape. 

Outlined below are Wall Street’s 10 ETFs that have the largest allocation towards META.

No. 1: GraniteShares 2x Long META Daily ETF (FBL), 99.96% allocation.

No. 2: Global X PureCap MSCI Communication Services ETF (GXPC), 26.45% allocation. 

No. 3: iShares Global Comm Services ETF (IXP), 21.93% allocation. 

No. 4: Fidelity MSCI Communication Services Index ETF (FCOM), 20.21% allocation.

No. 5: Vanguard Communication Services ETF (VOX), 20.02% allocation. 

No. 6: Roundhill META WeeklyPay ETF (METW), 19.93% allocation. 

No. 7: Communication Services Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLC), 15.21% allocation. 

No. 8: Direxion Daily Magnificent 7 Bull 2X Shares (QQQU), 11.98% allocation. 

No. 9: Direxion Daily META Bull 2X Shares (METU), 11.49% allocation. 

No. 10: ProShares Ultra Communication Services (LTL), 10.69% allocation. 

Meta Platforms Performance and Ratings

  • 1-Month: -9.6%.
  • 6-Month: +20.1%.
  • Year-to-Date: +12.5%.
  • SA Quant Rating: 3.47.
  • SA Analyst Rating: 4.15.
  • Wall Street Rating: 4.58.

data.title: Wall Street observes mixed moves after key big tech earnings and U.S.-China trade talks
data.description:
Wall Street is mixed on Thursday as Meta (META) and Microsoft (MSFT) earnings failed to impress investors. Market focus now has shifted to Apple (AAPL) and Amazon (AMZN) ahead of their reports, while traders also digest the latest updates from U.S.-China trade talks.

Falling the hardest has been the tech focused Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) which was last lower by 0.9%. At the same time, the benchmark S&P 500 (SP500) was in the red by 0.2%, and the blue-chip Dow (DJI) was higher by 0.7%. 

From a sector point of view, seven of the 11 S&P segments are trading up in the green with Financials leading the way. At the other end of the spectrum, the Info Tech space has suffered the most so far. 

U.S. Treasury yields inched higher as the longer-end U.S. 10-year Treasury yield (US10Y) pushed up 1 basis point to 4.08% and the shorter-end U.S. 2-year Treasury yield (US2Y) moved up by 1 basis point to 3.60%.

Earnings data from Meta Platforms (META) and Microsoft (MSFT) have dampened market momentum with META down 12.5% and MSFT lower by 3%. At the same time, Alphabet (GOOG)(GOOGL) has responded positively to its latest earnings figures as it has climbed 4.8%.

In the day ahead, traders will get more tech earnings, with Apple (AAPL) and Amazon (AMZN) set to report after the closing bell.

"We expect Amazon to miss expectations in its Thursday earnings report, and this is why we believed they pre-announced so many layoffs this week. Amazon's stock has underperformed and it's not as good of a business as many on Wall Street think," David Trainer, CEO of New Constructs said.

"We expect Apple to beat Wall Street's earnings expectations on the back of strong iPhone 17 sales. These strong iPhone sales show that even in this AI world, we still need a strong network of physical devices to drive AI adoption and use, and Apple is at the center of that, even if their AI strategy is minimal," Trainer added.

U.S. President Donald Trump announced a one-year agreement with China covering rare earths and critical minerals, while also halving fentanyl-related tariffs on Beijing (from 20% to 10%), effective immediately, following his meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in South Korea on Thursday.

"Despite its brevity, it appears that there was some progress in U.S.-China trade negotiations. But perhaps not quite as much as President Trump had signaled earlier this week...There was no word on either the future of Taiwan or TikTok. So, summing up the conclusion to this historic meeting: underwhelming," David Morrison, senior market analyst at Trade Nation, said. 

Furthermore, the Fed on Wednesday reduced its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.75%-4.00%, its second straight cut, as it seeks to ease off the brakes in an effort to protect the labor market.

data.title: Aptiv outlines $31B bookings target and EDS spin-off strategy amid trade and supply chain headwinds
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Aptiv PLC (APTV) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Kevin P. Clark, President, Chairman & CEO, stated that Aptiv “capitalized on the underlying growth in vehicle production in North America and Asia Pacific, while also continuing to experience strong revenue growth in nonautomotive markets.” He highlighted the company’s “resilient operating model” and noted that Aptiv is “progressing as planned with the separation of our Electrical Distribution Systems business by the end of the first quarter of 2026.”

  • Clark reported, “Our third quarter bookings of $8.4 billion validate customer confidence and strong market demand for our portfolio of advanced technologies.” He further commented that “revenues increased 6% to $5.2 billion,” and operating income “increased 10% to $654 million.” Earnings per share reached a record $2.17.

  • On strategic milestones, Clark remarked, “We continue to expect roughly $31 billion in new business bookings for the year, although timing of some program awards slated for the fourth quarter could shift into 2026.”

  • Varun Laroyia, Executive VP & CFO, stated, “Revenues were a record $5.2 billion, up 6% on an adjusted basis. Adjusted EBITDA and operating income grew 9% and 10%, respectively, also reaching record levels. And operating income margin expanded 30 basis points, primarily driven by strong volume flow-through, manufacturing performance and the benefits from our ongoing cost initiatives.” He noted an operating cash flow of $584 million and capital expenditures of $143 million.

Outlook

  • Clark announced an updated 2025 outlook: “We’re raising our full year 2025 guidance, reflecting the strength of our third quarter results, partially offset by recent customer-specific production disruptions and an outlook for the fourth quarter that prudently incorporates an element of conservatism to reflect the amplified trade tensions beginning to impact semiconductor supply chains.”

  • Laroyia provided specifics: “Our full year revenue outlook of $20.3 billion at the midpoint continues to reflect an adjusted growth rate of 2%. Adjusted EBITDA and operating income are expected to be approximately $3.22 billion and $2.45 billion at the midpoint, each up 4% versus the prior year.” Adjusted EPS is estimated in the range of $7.55 to $7.85, up 23% at the midpoint.

  • For Q4, Laroyia said, “Our fourth quarter guidance implies a revenue growth of 1% on an adjusted basis at the midpoint... operating income margin of 11.8% at the midpoint.”

Financial Results

  • Aptiv reported third quarter revenues of $5.2 billion, operating income of $654 million, and EPS of $2.17. Operating cash flow totaled $584 million, with $250 million deployed for share repurchases and debt paydown.

  • Segment results included flat revenues in Advanced Safety and User Experience (AS & UX), 6% revenue growth in Engineered Components Group (ECG), and 11% revenue growth in Electrical Distribution Systems (EDS).

  • A noncash goodwill impairment charge of $648 million for Wind River was recorded, attributed to “slower than originally expected growth in the business over 2023 and 2024, owing to delays in 5G adoption and the launch of software-defined vehicles.”

Q&A

  • Chris McNally, Evercore: Questioned the $80 million Q4 revenue headwind and regional impacts. Clark clarified, “It does encompass some volume impact associated with the facility issue or the facility fire in Oswego... there are other unique customer-specific situations with OEMs, including OEMs in Europe that are impacting our outlook for European production.”

  • McNally followed with concerns on chip supply and political risk. Clark replied, “It is a political issue between the Dutch government and China... product is flowing in China. So as we sit here today, it does not -- we're certainly not being impacted... we have roughly 3 months of inventory. We were confident we won't impact any OEMs in the fourth quarter.”

  • Joseph Spak, UBS: Asked about Q4 margin guidance and copper prices. Laroyia responded, “Three key pieces... flow-through on the weaker volumes... the one customer recovery... and then the final one... elevated copper prices.” Clark emphasized, “The year-over-year impact from an FX commodity standpoint is significant... north of 100 basis points on a year-over-year.”

  • Dan Levy, Barclays: Sought clarity on regional growth dynamics. Clark explained, “The bigger impacts for us in Europe and China tend to be tied to specific OEM volume issues... In China, the big impact for us this year were those 3 program cancellations that we talked about for NIO and Zeekr in the second quarter.”

  • James Picariello, BNP Paribas: Asked about active safety and user experience segments. Clark indicated, “Active safety growth in the quarter and back half of the year, we would expect that to be low single digits versus first half of the year kind of high single digits.” He added, “User experience... back half of the year will be down low double digits. We were down 10% in the third quarter.”

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed on supply chain disruptions, the impact of geopolitical trade issues, and margin headwinds, indicating a slightly negative to neutral tone, especially regarding earnings sustainability and guidance conservatism.

  • Management maintained a confident but cautious tone. Clark stated, “We’re confident we won't impact any OEMs in the fourth quarter,” and stressed proactive risk management. During prepared remarks, management tone was assertive and optimistic, while Q&A responses were more measured and sometimes defensive, especially when addressing uncertainties.

  • Compared to the previous quarter, both analysts and management appeared incrementally more concerned about external risks and the outlook for Q4, with analysts seeking more detail on downside scenarios.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The updated 2025 revenue outlook was raised from $20.15 billion in Q2 to $20.3 billion in Q3, with guidance for adjusted EPS also increased. Management attributed this to stronger-than-expected Q3 performance but noted increased conservatism for Q4, reflecting new supply chain and customer disruptions.

  • Strategic focus shifted more explicitly to the EDS spin-off, with a timeline reiterated for Q1 2026.

  • Analysts in both quarters focused on China mix, margin headwinds, and non-automotive growth, but Q3 featured more questions about geopolitical risks and supply chain resilience.

  • Management confidence remained solid in prepared remarks but was more qualified during Q&A, particularly around production outlook and margin impacts.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited “recent customer-specific production disruptions” and “amplified trade tensions beginning to impact semiconductor supply chains.”

  • Clark acknowledged, “the macro environment remains very dynamic with changing geopolitical trends, regulations and trade policies as well as customer-specific challenges, all of which are difficult to precisely forecast.”

  • Analysts repeatedly raised concerns about Q4 headwinds, supply chain risk, and the potential impact of political disputes on semiconductor supply, and sought reassurance on margin sustainability amid commodity and FX headwinds.

Final Takeaway

Aptiv’s third quarter showcased record financial performance and robust bookings, as management raised full-year guidance while acknowledging a more cautious stance for the fourth quarter due to supply chain disruptions, customer-specific issues, and global trade tensions. The company reaffirmed its commitment to the EDS spin-off, expects approximately $31 billion in new business bookings for the year, and highlighted continued growth in non-automotive markets. While management voiced confidence in Aptiv’s operational resilience and long-term prospects, the Q&A revealed heightened caution from both analysts and executives regarding near-term risks and external uncertainties.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Komercní banka, a.s. reports Q3 results
data.description:
• Komercní banka, a.s. press release (KMERF): Q3 group net income CZK 4.8 billion.
  • New sales of housing loans in 9M25 up by 48.2% YoY. Quarterly sales in Q3 the highest since 2021.

data.title: Fluidra sales up 5% to €1.72B, net profit jumps 33% to €163M in first nine months
data.description:
• Fluidra, S.A. press release (FLUIF): Reports sales were up 5% to €1,724 million and net profit up 33% to €163 million for the first nine months of the year.
  • Fluidra continues to make progress on its strategic priorities and is on track to deliver full-year 2025 guidance.

data.title: Qt Group Oyj reports Q3 results
data.description:
• Qt Group Oyj press release (QTGPF): Q3 net sales decreased 3.4% to EUR 40.7 million (EUR 42.2 million).
  • Earnings per share were EUR 0.06 (EUR 0.30).
  • Weaker than expected net sales growth contributed to weaker profitability in the third quarter of 2025.
  • Operating profit (EBITA) was EUR 4.3 million, and EBITA-margin was 10.5%.
  • Profitability decreased also due to one-off costs related to the acquisition of IAR, which totaled approximately EUR 1.7 million in July-September 2025, the company said.

data.title: Rithm Capital outlines $100B platform expansion amid Crestline and Paramount acquisitions
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Rithm Capital (RITM) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Michael Nierenberg, Chairman, President & CEO, opened the call highlighting strong performance across all business lines, stating "Our company had a great quarter with all of our business lines performing extremely well. Our market-leading business lines that enabled us to get here, Newrez, our mortgage company... Genesis, our construction lender... and our investment portfolio and team all had a really good quarter."
  • The company reported the acquisition of Crestline, a credit manager with $18-$20 billion in AUM, and Paramount, a large office REIT with properties in New York and San Francisco. Nierenberg emphasized, "We will not be raising equity in the capital markets to fund these acquisitions. We will fund these acquisitions with a combination of balance sheet and third-party LPs and partners."
  • Nierenberg described Crestline as bringing new direct lending, NAV lending, credit products, and an insurance and reinsurance business, stating "So now we're in the insurance business."
  • The CEO signaled a focus on performance and product breadth: "Our mantra of performance first will enable us to grow our platforms. We are not, to be clear, in an AUM race. More importantly, what we want to do is lead with results."
  • Regarding the Paramount acquisition, Nierenberg noted, "Acquiring assets for a little under $600 per foot versus replacement cost of $2,500 to $3,000 a foot gets us really excited... In New York, this portfolio is north of 90% leased. And in San Francisco, it's in the low 70s, creating a huge opportunity for us to grow NOI."
  • Nicola Santoro, CFO, stated, "At the end of the quarter, we ended with cash and cash equivalents on balance sheet of $1.6 billion... The expectation is at close, we will have approximately $1 billion of financing available to us. bringing us down to $1.3 billion of cash and cash equivalents post both the Crestline and Paramount transactions."
  • Baron Silverstein, President, reported, "Our third quarter '25 pretax income, excluding mark-to-market, was approximately $295 million, which is up 7% quarter-over-quarter and 20% year-over-year and delivered a 20% ROE for the quarter, continuing our steady performance."

Outlook

  • The CEO indicated sustained focus on results and platform growth: "Our mission is still the same, put up solid results quarter after quarter, be able to offer more products to our LPs and partners and take advantage of opportunistic situations to generate outsized returns and grow the company."
  • The company expects to close its first evergreen ABF fund in Q4 on a leading wealth management platform.
  • Nierenberg described optimism for the Paramount acquisition, noting demand trends: "We're seeing some of the highest leasing activity that we've seen, and this goes back to the pre-COVID days."
  • The company anticipates closing Crestline by December 1 and Paramount by mid-December, subject to shareholder approval.

Financial Results

  • Rithm generated approximately $300 million in earnings, producing an 18% ROE for the quarter.
  • Earnings available for distribution were $0.54 per diluted share, marking the 24th consecutive quarter where EAD exceeded dividends paid.
  • GAAP net income totaled $193.7 million or $0.35 per diluted share; return on equity was 11%.
  • Book value at quarter end stood at $12.83, totaling $7.1 billion.
  • Cash and liquidity on the balance sheet was reported at $2.2 billion.
  • Genesis Capital originated $1.2 billion in loans, representing a 60% year-over-year increase.

Q&A

  • Crispin Love, Piper Sandler: Asked about divergence in share price and strategic actions. Nierenberg responded, "We're not raising equity around this transaction for these assets... We need to drive more, quite frankly, more FRE through our pipes to get revalued."
  • Love queried on third-party capital for Paramount. Nierenberg replied, "We can raise all that money prior to close depending upon how much economics do we want to give away beforehand... The money is there."
  • Bose George, KBW: Inquired about the impact of Ginnie Mae streamline refis on margins. Silverstein responded, "They are definitely cheaper to produce... They're also highly competitive as well, but they're cheaper to produce."
  • George also questioned RPT growth options. Nierenberg answered, "We're looking at direct lending options and things like that. To the extent that we don't, at some point, we'll likely tender for the shares and just clean up the vehicle."
  • Eric Hagen, BTIG: Asked if third-party capital for Paramount would be used to pay down financing lines. Nierenberg: "Once we do close, to the extent that we do draw down, we'll pay that off once we raise the money."
  • Hagen queried about underwriting risks. Nierenberg stated, "We're underwriting first, and we don't just go out and buy pools of assets unless... we have the ability to hopefully control an outcome."
  • Jason Weaver, JonesTrading: Asked about ABF fund size and duration. Nierenberg indicated, "The size is likely going to be upwards of [ $500 million ] and then the average duration... in the kind of the 3-year area."
  • Weaver asked about dividend policy. Nierenberg replied, "We're not going to raise our dividend... there's no desire to increase the dividend at this point."
  • Trevor Cranston, Citizens JMP: Inquired about share buybacks. Nierenberg said, "We're not going to be doing share buybacks here. I think the question around a potential IPO of the mortgage company is always something that we wrestle with."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts focused on valuation gaps, capital allocation, and strategic options, often pressing for more concrete timelines and clarification on plans, reflecting a neutral to slightly negative tone.
  • Management maintained confidence during prepared remarks, but responses in Q&A were occasionally defensive, particularly when discussing share price and capital allocation, as shown in phrases like "We're not going to raise equity around this transaction" and "there's no desire to increase the dividend at this point."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management's tone became more assertive in explaining capital deployment and acquisition funding, while analysts remained concerned about valuation and growth execution.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter was marked by the announcement of two significant acquisitions (Crestline and Paramount), compared to a previous focus on organic growth and smaller scale M&A.
  • Financial results showed continued EAD coverage of dividends and stable per-share metrics, with a slight increase in book value and liquidity compared to the prior quarter.
  • Strategic focus shifted from primarily asset management and origination growth to platform expansion through acquisition, including entry into the insurance business.
  • Analysts in both quarters remained focused on valuation realization and strategic transactions, but current questions placed more emphasis on the implications of M&A and capital structure.
  • Management's confidence in acquisitions and capital allocation was more pronounced this quarter, highlighted by repeated assurances that no equity would be raised for new deals.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management noted concerns about market valuation, emphasizing the need to grow asset management fee-related earnings to achieve revaluation.
  • Underwriting standards were highlighted as a risk area, with Nierenberg referencing recent industry fraud cases and stressing internal controls: "Underwriting first."
  • Analysts questioned the sustainability of dividend coverage, capital allocation discipline, and the ability to raise third-party capital for large acquisitions.
  • The integration of acquired entities, especially the insurance business via Crestline, was identified as a challenge, though management expressed confidence in execution.

Final Takeaway

Management underscored a transformative quarter with the acquisitions of Crestline and Paramount, expanding Rithm Capital's platform beyond $100 billion in investable assets. Emphasis remains on delivering consistent results, expanding product offerings for LPs, and generating outsized returns, while maintaining a disciplined approach to capital allocation without raising equity. Integration of new business lines and realization of cross-platform synergies are expected to drive future value for shareholders and partners.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Enbridge Line 5 reroute around Wisconsin reservation approved by U.S. Army Corps
data.description:
The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers on Wednesday approved Enbridge's (ENB) application to reroute the aging Line 5 oil pipeline around a northern Wisconsin tribal reservation.

Enbridge's (ENB) 41-mile reroute was proposed to move the pipeline off land held by the Bad River Band of Lake Superior Chippewa; 12 miles of pipeline must be removed from the Bad River Band's land by June 2026, as designated by court order.

The permits for the Line 5 reroute were announced with little detail, and no supporting documents about the approval were issued.

The new $450 million pipeline route will cross more than 180 Lake Superior tributaries, including the Bad River, and environmental groups criticized the Army Corps decision to grant the federal permit as "premature and unlawful" as litigation continues over state permits.

Enbridge (ENB) has been using Line 5 to transport crude oil and natural gas liquids between Superior, Wisconsin, and Sarnia, Ontario, since 1953.

The Wisconsin project is separate from Enbridge's (ENB) plan to build a protective tunnel to encase a different segment of Line 5 in Michigan that runs for four miles beneath the Straits of Mackinac linking Lake Michigan and Lake Huron; litigation is ongoing.
